articles.headline: A Rough and Bawdy Ad Magnet
articles.snippet: FX has consciously carved a niche in the new television landscape, following a blueprint to lure younger viewers whom marketers pay a premium to reach.
articles.abstract: FX has consciously carved a niche in the new television landscape, following a blueprint to lure younger viewers whom marketers pay a premium to reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: What would you call a comedy about a suicidal depressive who befriends a talking dog, or a bloody horror drama featuring a dysfunctional family living in a haunted house?
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Justices Send Back Gene Case
articles.snippet: Appellate judges were told to reconsider a ruling that let Myriad Genetics patent two genes associated with a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer.
articles.abstract: Appellate judges were told to reconsider a ruling that let Myriad Genetics patent two genes associated with a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday ordered an appeals court to reconsider its decision to uphold patents held by Myriad Genetics on two genes associated with a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer.

articles.headline: German Leader Agrees to More Bailout Money for Euro Zone Nations
articles.snippet: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said a new 500 billion euro fund could operate in tandem with a temporary one that still has money.
articles.abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said a new 500 billion euro fund could operate in tandem with a temporary one that still has money.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union took a big step on Monday toward building a financial firewall strong enough to prevent the spread of fiscal contagion to major economies like Spain. The move came after Germany dropped its opposition to bringing the Continent’s total bailout capacity to more than 690 billion euros ( $916 billion).
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Support in U.S. for Afghan War Drops Sharply, Poll Finds
articles.snippet: A New York Times/CBS News poll found that 69 percent of Americans surveyed think that the United States should not be at war in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: A New York Times/CBS News poll found that 69 percent of Americans surveyed think that the United States should not be at war in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a series of violent episodes and setbacks, support for the war in Afghanistan has dropped sharply among both Republicans and Democrats, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Allison Kopicki

articles.headline: As Health Law Is Contested, Developing a Plan B
articles.snippet: State officials and insurance executives are devising alternatives to the coming federal requirement that most Americans buy health insurance.
articles.abstract: State officials and insurance executives are devising alternatives to the coming federal requirement that most Americans buy health insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: State officials and insurance executives are devising possible alternatives to the coming federal requirement that most Americans buy health insurance, even as the Supreme Court hears arguments about the constitutionality of the mandate.

articles.headline: Vindication for Challenger of Health Care Law
articles.snippet: Randy E. Barnett, a Georgetown law professor, has argued long and loud that the requirement to buy health insurance is unconstitutional.
articles.abstract: Randy E. Barnett, a Georgetown law professor, has argued long and loud that the requirement to buy health insurance is unconstitutional.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Congress passed legislation requiring nearly all Americans to obtain health insurance, Randy E. Barnett, a passionate libertarian who teaches law at Georgetown, argued that the bill was unconstitutional. Many of his colleagues, on both the left and the right, dismissed the idea as ridiculous — and still do.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: New Ideas on Pensions: Use States
articles.snippet: Some state officials are considering a novel proposal to rebuild America’s ailing retirement system: having state pension funds run retirement plans for companies.
articles.abstract: Some state officials are considering a novel proposal to rebuild America’s ailing retirement system: having state pension funds run retirement plans for companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: As growing numbers of baby boomers face retirement with inadequate savings, some state officials are considering a novel proposal to rebuild America’s ailing retirement system — having state pension funds run retirement plans for companies.

articles.headline: Foxconn Gets Japan Foothold With Stake in Sharp
articles.snippet: The share issue will give the main manufacturer of Apple devices about an 11 percent stake in Sharp, making it the top shareholder in Japan’s leader in LCD technology.
articles.abstract: The share issue will give the main manufacturer of Apple devices about an 11 percent stake in Sharp, making it the top shareholder in Japan’s leader in LCD technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In another sign of China’s manufacturing ascent as Japan struggles, the Taiwanese giant Foxconn Technology will become the largest shareholder in Sharp, a former exemplar of Japan’s electronics empire that has fallen on hard times.

articles.headline: Florida’s New Election Law Blunts Voter Drives
articles.snippet: New restrictions have led groups like Rock the Vote and the League of Women Voters to curb their efforts.
articles.abstract: New restrictions have led groups like Rock the Vote and the League of Women Voters to curb their efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Florida, which is expected to be a vital swing state once again in this year’s presidential election, is enrolling fewer new voters than it did four years ago as prominent civic organizations have suspended registration drives because of what they describe as onerous restrictions imposed last year by Republican state officials.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Jo Craven McGinty
